Posts.Content: Hello What is the different between MRI to Bone Scan To check for metastasis from Prostate Cancer? What is better?
Posts.Title: MRI Or CT

Posts.Content: Hello What is the different between MRI to Bone Scan To check for metastasis from Prostate Cancer? What is better?
Posts.Title: MRI Or CT

Posts.Content: Also I would like to ask what is the different between NRI To CT to diagnose metastasis from Prostate Cancer? Originally Posted by DjinTonic The MRI is good for imaging soft tissue--the prostate itself and metastases to other body organs. When it metastasizes, however, prostate cancer has a particular affinity for bone, which is very dense. The bone scan, done with radioactive (but safe) dye, is designed specifically for that. Since they look primarily at different things, one isn't "better" than the other. When there is a concern that high-grade cancer has possibly spread by metastasis, the doc usually wants to check both, bones and body organs. Having this information can, of course, influence treatment decisions. Before surgery, the MRI can also tell the doc if anything untoward (besides prostate cancer) is going on.
Posts.Title: MRI Or CT

Posts.Title: Any recommendations on prostate surgeons

Posts.Content: 64 years s old, prostate cancer Gleason 4/5 PSA 8, looking for the most experience seurgon And Doctors in Los Angeles area Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Please provide us with some details about your diagnosis. Yesterday, you asked about scans for metastasis. Surgery is of little use if prostate cancer has metastasized. You would then be dealing with a medical oncologist, not a urologist/surgeon. If we know more about your situation, we can try to provide the best answers.

Posts.Content: Hello, My husband diagnosed with Prostate Cancer. Can you please tell me who is the best surgical urology and who is the best prostate cancer onocolgy in the California and nation wide? What is the best medic center in the US for prostate Cancer? Who is the best Doctor for advance Prostate Cancer? Thank you very much.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer doctor

Posts.Content: Thank you. Who are the best Doctors for prostate cancer in the US?
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer doctor

Posts.Content: Thank you everybody Originally Posted by DjinTonic Your may want to consider an open procedure rather than robotic if the cancer is high-grade and you opt for surgery. DavefromMD posted that Dr. Alan Partin, an expert at both approaches, wanted the open for Dave, and so did Dave, who relates that Dr Partin would choose an open for himself, should he need it. So did my Uro/surgeon and so did I after research. Some of the advantages touted for open are having tactile feedback to help detect cancerous tissue and better access to more lymph nodes. I'm not knocking robotic at all, and in the end you should give great weight to whichever your doc feels is the best approach. Just keep an open mind. Consult1 makes a very important point: you want a surgeon who does a high volume RPs--you improve your chances of a good outcome. This point about the surgeon's experience is often emphasized in journal studies of approaches and outcomes.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer doctor

Posts.Content: Thank you very much for your reply My husband 64, PSA 7.8, prostate biopsy 4/5 We live near to LA, I'm worry all day, Do you know who Are the best Doctors in the State, also Is it reccomend to send his biopsy to second Opinion with Doctor Epstein? [/QUOTE]If that is your situation, there are a number of places you can travel to. Mayo Clinic has the largest prostate cancer database in the world and, as a hospital, is ranked number one for the second year in a row (for all medical services combined). Equal to them would be Cleveland Clinic, MD Anderson, Johns Hopkins and several others. Others will jump in to add to this list. Wishing you the best and, if you can, please list all of your stats (biopsy, any treatments, etc) so we can have a better understanding of your situaiton. Good luck! Chuck[/QUOTE]

Posts.Title: How can I find data of the most experience seurgons

Posts.Content: Thank you for your help Originally Posted by DjinTonic Prostate-specific Antigen Velocity Risk Count to Discern Significant From Indolent Prostate Cancer https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4191640/ [2014] The above is positive regarding PSAV, but the authors cite studies that question the utility of it in clinical practice. From the Discussion Certainly for post-treatment patients, the doubling time factors in. For screening, there may not be enough precise data that's in agreement to build it into the nomograms that the calculators are based on.
